intro: Dalechampia trifoliata, commonly known as the three-leaved cupplant, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its unique, cup-like structure at the base of its flower cluster. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments and has alternate, trifoliate leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are unisexual, with separate male and female flowers on the same plant, and it produces small, fleshy fruits. Dalechampia trifoliata is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has traditional uses in some indigenous cultures.
